Articles.Content:
You need Landers, no problem! No credit check, no down!

Financing available on all qualifying launch vehicles!

Land somewhere today!

The Astra

First up, a fairly simple design. I imagine the real value is in the stable launch vehicle that puts a lander into orbit and has enough dv to drop into lunar orbit before separation.

3x4 Skipper engines power stage Five with x4 T30's overlapping into stage Four. Preset throttle to minimum 80% and launch.

When you have a sliver of fuel left on stage Five, light stage Four. Five should expire seconds later if you time it correctly.

Execute stage Three to to drop the Skippers; throttle up T30s to 100% simultaneously. They should drop away cleanly.

Burn to orbit.

The Astra lander is a simple, centerline design. A Poodle provides the horsepower while 4 1x6 solar panels supplement power.

She's good for there and back. This lander is designed to return in one piece, so simply de-orbit and deploy chutes at the appropriate time.

Suggest a fuel load of less than 50% when you pop the chutes and a descent of less than 12m/s to withstand touchdown.

Landing lights are provided along the landing struts to provide depth during low light descents.

The Excelion

The launch vehicle is basically the same as the Astra, just with a bit more fuel and a couple more T30s in stage Six (six to be exact).

She won't have enough juice to break Kerbin orbit by herself, but it will give you a healthy start on it.

Same basic launch profile as the Astra. The payload is heavier, so preset throttle to 100% and launch.

Once there's only a hair's worth of fuel left on stage Seven, activate stage Six to burn concurrently.

Seven should empty seconds later. Use stage Five to dump the boosters and ramp back to 100% (assuming you throttled back to conserve fuel on the way up).

Burn to Orbit.

The Excelion lander is a different animal entirely. Four 909s provide the lander with it's primary thrust and there's plenty of fuel for at least two neighborhood landings.

Power comes in the form of 4 1x6 solar panels, and landing lights are standard equipment.

The main difference is in how we handle atmospheric landings. The Excelion lander can be landed full and intact, or as the stand alone command module. Or both.

Stage Two will pop the primary chutes. Dump at least 50% of the fuel before hand to maintain structural integrity and ensure your drop is no more than 12m/s on landing.

Stage One will separate and boost the command module clear of Stage two in case of WTF. Stage zero deploy those chutes. You probably will survive this as long as you're over 500m

You can actually land both modules intact (assuming you deployed the gear on stage two first).

And, um, no file attachment ability anymore?
